abstract: Company boards are attracted to share buybacks when markets are down, but the purchase often ends up damaging the value of a stock.
snippet: Company boards are attracted to share buybacks when markets are down, but the purchase often ends up damaging the value of a stock.
lead_paragraph: Share buybacks are creeping back into fashion. Lowe’s and CVS Caremark divulged plans for $9 billion worth between them this week. Such repurchases become more enticing when markets are on their knees. But boards have too often sanctioned programs that destroy value. They need to resist the rising temptation.

headline.main: The Negative Side of Share Buybacks
headline.print_headline: The Negative Side Of Share Buybacks

byline.original: By ROBERT COLE and QUENTIN WEBB
